p: Since the discovery of the first coronaviruses (CoV) by Tyrrell and Bynoe in 1965 [ 1], more strains have emerged. Only two circulating human coronaviruses (HCoVs), HCoV-229E [ 2] and HCoV-OC43 [ 3], were described as the frequent cause of the common cold until 2002â€“2003 when the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS)-CoV spread into the human population in China [ 4, 5]. Then, two new coronaviruses, CoV NL63 in 2004 (alphacoronavirus) [ 6] and HKU1 in 2005 (betacoronavirus) [ 7], were discovered. Another coronavirus, the MERS-CoV, emerged in the Middle East and engenders lower respiratory tract infections with high mortality [ 8].
